repo.description: The most widely used Python to C compiler
repo.name: cython

body:
Add `embedsignature.pure` compiler directive to generate pure-Python type annotations compatible with type hinting syntax. This mostly amounts to:
* Not emitting C type declarations in signatures.
* Preferring explicit argument type annotations over C types.
* Mapping C type names to the closest Python type name.

See https://github.com/cython/cython/issues/3150

comment_data.body:
This probably breaks the type check in fused types, removing support for `long` in Py2:
https://github.com/cython/cython/blob/236e705d644247415baacf0a6d38b6e85379cce1/Cython/Compiler/FusedNode.py#L296-L304

There are other usages of the method, but this is the only one that I could find that breaks. Thus, special-casing `int` in the fused types type checking code seems a reasonable fix. It would also make the `py_type_name()` method cleaner again.
What is this for?
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -54,6 +54,9 @@ def __init__(self, context):
         self.class_name = None
         self.class_node = None
 
+    def _select_format(self, embed, clinic):
+        return embed

comment_data.body:
That's for a future enhancement I was planning. I should have added a comment about this.

The idea is to support the `__text_signature__` function attribute you get from Python's argument clinic to support `inspect.signature()`. But this would only be useful if setting explicitly the compiler option `binding = False`, otherwise Cython functions work just fine with `inspect.signature()`.

On a second thought, I may very well get rid of this thing. What would be your preference?
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -54,6 +54,9 @@ def __init__(self, context):
         self.class_name = None
         self.class_node = None
 
+    def _select_format(self, embed, clinic):
+        return embed

comment_data.body: The test in this like makes sure a Python 2 `long` is properly dispatched.
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -401,6 +401,40 @@ def test_cython_numeric(cython.numeric arg):
     """
     print cython.typeof(arg), arg
 
+
+cdef fused int_t:
+    int
+
+cdef _test_pylong(int_t i):
+    print cython.typeof(i)
+
+def test_pylong(int_t i):
+    """
+    >>> import cython
+    >>> try:    long = long # Python 2
+    ... except: long = int  # Python 3
+
+    >>> test_pylong[int](int(0))
+    int
+    >>> test_pylong[cython.int](int(0))
+    int
+    >>> test_pylong(int(0))
+    int
+
+    >>> test_pylong[int](long(0))
+    int
+    >>> test_pylong[cython.int](long(0))
+    int
+    >>> test_pylong(long(0))

comment_data.body: I had the suspicion I was breaking something. I did my best to address this issue. Let's continue the discussion in the other two comments I added after my changes. I'm resolving this one.
This is my attempt to support int/long under Python 2. Does it look good enough?
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -293,8 +293,12 @@ def _fused_instance_checks(self, normal_types, pyx_code, env):
         """
         for specialized_type in normal_types:
             # all_numeric = all_numeric and specialized_type.is_numeric
+            py_type_name = specialized_type.py_type_name()
+            if py_type_name == 'int':
+                # Support Python 2 long
+                py_type_name = '(int, long)'

comment_data.body: I removed the method and left some `# clinic: xxx` comments to keep around what should be used for the argument clinic format.

comment_data.body: Looks good to me.
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -293,8 +293,12 @@ def _fused_instance_checks(self, normal_types, pyx_code, env):
         """
         for specialized_type in normal_types:
             # all_numeric = all_numeric and specialized_type.is_numeric
+            py_type_name = specialized_type.py_type_name()
+            if py_type_name == 'int':
+                # Support Python 2 long
+                py_type_name = '(int, long)'

comment_data.body:
I never considered having both a C type declaration and a Python type declaration for the same argument. Not sure if it's a good idea to allow (and even encourage) that. I can see in your test examples that it works (apparently), and I can see it being useful in order to disambiguate C type declarations. However, we're currently trying to discourage C type declarations in favour of type annotations in Python syntax, and this counters that.

```suggestion
``embedsignature.pure`` (True / False)
    If set to True, Cython will do its best attempt to use
    pure-Python type annotations in embedded signatures.  If arguments
    have explicit Python type annotations, these are preferred over C type
    declarations.  Otherwise, declared C types are mapped to the closest
    Python type equivalent (e.g., C ``short`` is mapped to Python ``int`` type
    and C ``double`` is mapped to Python ``float`` type). 
    Implies ``embedsignature=True``.  Default is False.

```
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -854,6 +854,14 @@ Cython code.  Here is the list of currently supported directives:
     signature, which cannot otherwise be retrieved after
     compilation.  Default is False.
 
+``embedsignature.pure`` (True / False)
+    If set to True, Cython will do a its best attempt to use
+    pure-Python type annotations in embedded signatures. If arguments
+    have explicit type annotations, these are preferred over C
+    types. Otherwise, C types are mapped to the closest Python type
+    equivalent (e.g., C ``short`` is mapped to Python ``int`` type and
+    C ``double`` is mapped to Python ``float`` type).  Default is False.
+

comment_data.body:
I don't think the `cdef` function is of any use here. There is no internal dispatch since both functions use the same fused type.
```suggestion
def test_pylong(int_t i):
    """
    >>> import cython
    >>> try:    long = long # Python 2
    ... except: long = int  # Python 3

    >>> test_pylong[int](int(0))
    int
    >>> test_pylong[cython.int](int(0))
    int
    >>> test_pylong(int(0))
    int

    >>> test_pylong[int](long(0))
    int
    >>> test_pylong[cython.int](long(0))
    int
    >>> test_pylong(long(0))
    int

    >>> test_pylong[cython.long](0)  # doctest: +ELLIPSIS
    Traceback (most recent call last):
    KeyError: ...
    """
    print(cython.typeof(i))
```
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -401,6 +401,40 @@ def test_cython_numeric(cython.numeric arg):
     """
     print cython.typeof(arg), arg
 
+
+cdef fused int_t:
+    int
+
+cdef _test_pylong(int_t i):
+    print cython.typeof(i)
+
+def test_pylong(int_t i):
+    """
+    >>> import cython
+    >>> try:    long = long # Python 2
+    ... except: long = int  # Python 3

+    >>> test_pylong[int](int(0))

+    >>> test_pylong(int(0))

+

+    int
+    >>> test_pylong[cython.int](long(0))
+    int
+    >>> test_pylong(long(0))
+    int
+
+    >>> test_pylong[cython.long](0)  # doctest: +ELLIPSIS
+    Traceback (most recent call last):
+    KeyError: ...
+    """
+    _test_pylong(i)

comment_data.body:
Remember that "Python type declarations" are actually just annotations. 

If you want to reject arguments with both C types and annotations, you will make my life miserable, I'll have a lot of work to do in mpi4py to accomodate for that change, to the point that you would force me to remove all C types form arguments of `def` functions. 

Moreover, your call will prevent users for doing some very reasonable stuff, For example

```python
def foo(int arg: Annotated[int, MaxValueAllowed(42)]) -> Any:
    ...
```
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -854,6 +854,14 @@ Cython code.  Here is the list of currently supported directives:
     signature, which cannot otherwise be retrieved after
     compilation.  Default is False.
 
+``embedsignature.pure`` (True / False)
+    If set to True, Cython will do a its best attempt to use
+    pure-Python type annotations in embedded signatures. If arguments
+    have explicit type annotations, these are preferred over C
+    types. Otherwise, C types are mapped to the closest Python type
+    equivalent (e.g., C ``short`` is mapped to Python ``int`` type and
+    C ``double`` is mapped to Python ``float`` type).  Default is False.
+

comment_data.body: So, what happens if `emberdignature.format=clinic` and `binding=True`?
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -854,6 +854,20 @@ Cython code.  Here is the list of currently supported directives:
     signature, which cannot otherwise be retrieved after
     compilation.  Default is False.
 
+``embedsignature.format`` (``c`` / ``python`` / ``clinic``)
+    If set to ``c``, Cython will generate signatures preserving
+    C type declarations and Python type annotations. If set to
+    ``python``, Cython will do a its best attempt to use pure-Python
+    type annotations in embedded signatures. For arguments without
+    Python type annotations, the C type is mapped to the closest
+    Python type equivalent (e.g., C ``short`` is mapped to Python
+    ``int`` type and C ``double`` is mapped to Python ``float`` type).
+    The specific output and type mapping are experimental and may
+    change over time.  If set to ``clinic`` and the ``binding``
+    directive is set to False, Cython will generate signatures
+    compatible with CPython's Argument Clinic. Default is
+    ``c``.

comment_data.body:
I think we can afford calling these `format_is_clinic` etc. `self.is_clinic` reads funny and `self.is_python/cython` is also not very clear.

I'm also not a big fan of `underscore_` names. Why not call it `signature_format` or `format_name` instead?
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -66,28 +66,47 @@ def _fmt_annotation(self, node):
         # print(type(node).__name__, '-->', result)
         return result
 
-    def _fmt_arg(self, arg):
-        if arg.type is PyrexTypes.py_object_type or arg.is_self_arg:
-            doc = arg.name
-        else:
-            doc = arg.type.declaration_code(arg.name, for_display=1)
+    def _setup_format(self):
+        format_ = self.current_directives['embedsignature.format']
+        self.is_cython = format_ == 'cython'
+        self.is_python = format_ == 'python'
+        self.is_clinic = format_ == 'clinic'

comment_data.body:
No signature is generated, because CythonFunction does not support the  `__text_signature__` descriptor like CPython's `builtin_function_or_method`.

How would you like to rephrase the documentation?

As I told you before, this `clinic` format is of little use in Cython 3.
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -854,6 +854,20 @@ Cython code.  Here is the list of currently supported directives:
     signature, which cannot otherwise be retrieved after
     compilation.  Default is False.
 
+``embedsignature.format`` (``c`` / ``python`` / ``clinic``)
+    If set to ``c``, Cython will generate signatures preserving
+    C type declarations and Python type annotations. If set to
+    ``python``, Cython will do a its best attempt to use pure-Python
+    type annotations in embedded signatures. For arguments without
+    Python type annotations, the C type is mapped to the closest
+    Python type equivalent (e.g., C ``short`` is mapped to Python
+    ``int`` type and C ``double`` is mapped to Python ``float`` type).
+    The specific output and type mapping are experimental and may
+    change over time.  If set to ``clinic`` and the ``binding``
+    directive is set to False, Cython will generate signatures
+    compatible with CPython's Argument Clinic. Default is
+    ``c``.

comment_data.body:
> As I told you before, this `clinic` format is of little use in Cython 3.

Perhaps a stupid question, but why include it at all then?

```suggestion
    ``python``, Cython will do a best attempt to use pure-Python
```
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -854,6 +854,20 @@ Cython code.  Here is the list of currently supported directives:
     signature, which cannot otherwise be retrieved after

+    C type declarations and Python type annotations. If set to

comment_data.body:
Personally I'd say "The clinic format generates signatures that can be understood by CPython's argument clinic tool and used to generate the `__text_signature__` attribute.  This mainly useful when `binding=False`, since the functions generated with `binding=True` do not have a `__text_signature__` attribute."

I'm not sure I'd disable it when `binding=True` (even if it's a bit pointless there).
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -854,6 +854,20 @@ Cython code.  Here is the list of currently supported directives:
     signature, which cannot otherwise be retrieved after
     compilation.  Default is False.
 
+``embedsignature.format`` (``c`` / ``python`` / ``clinic``)
+    If set to ``c``, Cython will generate signatures preserving
+    C type declarations and Python type annotations. If set to
+    ``python``, Cython will do a its best attempt to use pure-Python
+    type annotations in embedded signatures. For arguments without
+    Python type annotations, the C type is mapped to the closest
+    Python type equivalent (e.g., C ``short`` is mapped to Python
+    ``int`` type and C ``double`` is mapped to Python ``float`` type).
+    The specific output and type mapping are experimental and may
+    change over time.  If set to ``clinic`` and the ``binding``
+    directive is set to False, Cython will generate signatures
+    compatible with CPython's Argument Clinic. Default is
+    ``c``.

comment_data.body: "little use" does not mean "no use". Those that for whatever reason want to set `binding=False` may find the new option useful to get `__text_signature__` and then the `inspect` module to work closer to CPython builtin functions and methods.
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -854,6 +854,20 @@ Cython code.  Here is the list of currently supported directives:

+    If set to ``c``, Cython will generate signatures preserving

+    ``python``, Cython will do a its best attempt to use pure-Python
+    type annotations in embedded signatures. For arguments without
+    Python type annotations, the C type is mapped to the closest
+    Python type equivalent (e.g., C ``short`` is mapped to Python

+    The specific output and type mapping are experimental and may
+    change over time.  If set to ``clinic`` and the ``binding``
+    directive is set to False, Cython will generate signatures
+    compatible with CPython's Argument Clinic. Default is
+    ``c``.

comment_data.body: @da-woods I reworded the documentation as  per your comments. Note however that the argument clinic tool does not generate signatures, instead, you have to write them by hand following the proper format.
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -854,6 +854,25 @@ Cython code.  Here is the list of currently supported directives:
     signature, which cannot otherwise be retrieved after
     compilation.  Default is False.
 
+``embedsignature.format`` (``c`` / ``python`` / ``clinic``)

comment_data.body:
> I'm not sure I'd disable it when binding=True (even if it's a bit pointless there).

Is not only that is pointless. it looks awful as well, e,g

```
($self, *args, **kwargs)
--
<BLANKLINE>
<BLANKLINE>
Function docstring goes here.
```
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -854,6 +854,20 @@ Cython code.  Here is the list of currently supported directives:
     signature, which cannot otherwise be retrieved after
     compilation.  Default is False.
 
+``embedsignature.format`` (``c`` / ``python`` / ``clinic``)
+    If set to ``c``, Cython will generate signatures preserving
+    C type declarations and Python type annotations. If set to
+    ``python``, Cython will do a its best attempt to use pure-Python
+    type annotations in embedded signatures. For arguments without
+    Python type annotations, the C type is mapped to the closest
+    Python type equivalent (e.g., C ``short`` is mapped to Python
+    ``int`` type and C ``double`` is mapped to Python ``float`` type).
+    The specific output and type mapping are experimental and may
+    change over time.  If set to ``clinic`` and the ``binding``
+    directive is set to False, Cython will generate signatures
+    compatible with CPython's Argument Clinic. Default is
+    ``c``.

comment_data.body:
```suggestion
    The ``clinic`` format generates signatures that are compatible
    with those understood by CPython's Argument Clinic tool. The
    CPython runtime strips these signatures from docstrings and
    translates them into a ``__text_signature__`` attribute. This is
    mainly useful when using ``binding=False``, since the Cython
    functions generated with ``binding=True`` do not have (nor need)
    a ``__text_signature__`` attribute.
```
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -854,6 +854,25 @@ Cython code.  Here is the list of currently supported directives:
     signature, which cannot otherwise be retrieved after
     compilation.  Default is False.
 
+``embedsignature.format`` (``c`` / ``python`` / ``clinic``)
+    If set to ``c``, Cython will generate signatures preserving
+    C type declarations and Python type annotations.
+    If set to ``python``, Cython will do a best attempt to use
+    pure-Python type annotations in embedded signatures. For arguments
+    without Python type annotations, the C type is mapped to the
+    closest Python type equivalent (e.g., C ``short`` is mapped to
+    Python ``int`` type and C ``double`` is mapped to Python ``float``
+    type).  The specific output and type mapping are experimental and
+    may change over time.
+    The ``clinic`` format generates signatures that are compatible
+    with those used with the CPython's Argument Clinic tool. The
+    CPython runtime strips these signatures from docstrings and
+    translates them into a ``__text_signature__`` attribute. This is
+    mainly useful when using ``binding=False``, since the Cython
+    functions generated with ``binding=True`` do not have a
+    ``__text_signature__`` attribute.

repo.description: The most widely used Python to C compiler
repo.name: cython

milestone.description:
Goals:
 New version scheme: 3.x instead of 0.x.
 Change default `language_level` from `2` to `3str`.
 Change default for `binding` directive from `False` to `True`.
 Fix some Python compatibility issues (if possible, allowing for breaking changes).

title: Enhancements to autodoc/embedsignature
